Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Spatially controlled direct transfer printing of semiconductor components for high-performance flexible electronic devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I is the development of a disruptive manufacturing technology that will enable a new class of nanomembrane-based electronic devices to be assembled and integrated on flexible substrates. This innovative technology promises to provide flexible electronics developers and manufacturers a new option for fabricating a wide range of flexible devices that require the integration of high-performance semiconductors. It is anticipated that printing tools and processes based on this core technology will significantly lower the technological barriers that are hindering the widespread manufacture of next-generation flexible devices.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop a direct printing tool that surpasses the available technologies in terms of both precision and scalability. Current flexible device manufacturing processes do not have the capabilities needed to realize high-performance flexible devices through the integration of high-quality semiconductor materials. Therefore, new strategies are required for fabricating and printing the thin device layers that are essential in emerging high-performance flexible electronics. This project will involve mechanics simulations,tool design and fabrication, process experiments to meet resolution and yield metrics, and establishment of design constraints and operating conditions for a manufacturing process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flexible hybrid electronics (FHE), the emerging application area that motivates this research, is pushing the envelope of high-performance electronic devices on flexible substrates. Our novel technology and supporting processes respond to the critical manufacturing challenge of selecting and directly printing a wide range of thin, high-performance semiconducting components onto flexible substrates. Our approach exploits the flexibility of thin, polymeric substrates in an original way by handling the substrate as both a stamp and as the destination substrate. This unique approach promises to provide flexible-electronics developers and manufacturers an unprecedented option for fabricating a wide range of flexible devices that require the integration of thin and ultra-thin high-performance semiconductors on a common substrate. We anticipate that printing tools and processes based on our core technology will significantly lower the technological barriers that are hindering the widespread manufacture of next-generation, high-performance, fully flexible electronic devices with broad applications, including those in healthcare, structural health monitoring, and wearable consumer electronics.

Several key outcomes resulted from the one-year Phase I STTR project. In order to reduce the core direct-printing concept to practice, we designed, built, and demonstrated a semi-automatic research tool to transfer 300-nm-thick single-crystalline silicon membranes directly onto 50-µm-thick polyethylene terephthalate sheets with a placement accuracy of better than 10 µm. To understand the fundamental mechanics of the direct-printing process, we performed mechanics modeling of the direct-transfer process, which revealed a process window within which our novel printing process can be implemented successfully. We developed and implemented a unique process for patterning plastic sheets before and after the silicon components were printed in order to guide component placement during printing and subsequent metallization after printing. Finally, we developed innovations in sheet handling, sheet alignment, and imaging to address the challenges associated with reducing the core printing concept to practice, and we are pursuing patent protection on those concepts. We will be submitting the modeling and experimental printing results from the Phase I project for peer-reviewed publication.

New directions in flexible-device research and product development will be enabled by our innovative approach, which lies at the intersection of mechanics, electronics, and materials science. Intellectual output from this work will enhance our fundamental understanding of the capabilities and limitations of direct transfer printing, and will advance our knowledge of practical design constraints for high-precision, high-throughput printing of FHE components. Furthermore, our disruptive technology will enable the manufacture of a new class of fully flexible electronics. The impact of these devices on the market and on daily life has the potential to be transformative, with everything from consumer devices (e.g., flexible phones and tablets), to imaging and sensing, to healthcare and homeland security being affected by advancements in manufacturing within the field of FHE. New tools that enable the high-volume manufacturing of FHE devices are crucial for the full potential of FHE to be realized.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2016
Modified by: David S Grierson
